Without revenge from hence I will not go.
Revenge to my enraged Soul ſhall be,
My Throne, my Jove, my Heavenly Dignity.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Nay then I'le govern your Imperious hate.
You Airy Spirits that on Tempeſts wait:
That all the Forces of the Air command;
Rain, Thunder, Lightning, Muſter or Disband,
Employ 'em when, and againſt whom I pleaſe,
Vice-roys of all the ſpreading Provinces.
'Twixt Earth and Moon, quick with your Guards appear,
And take the loudeſt of all Tempeſts here:
Your Queen from hence,—and keep her cloſe confin'd,
In the cold Rooms, where Hail and Snow you grind,
Where with more fit Companions ſhe may be,
With Storms that can reply as loud as ſhe;
Where ſhe her fill of noiſe may take,
Rail as ſhe will, and no diſturbance make:
And do not dare to let her ſcape from thence,
Till of her duty ſhe has learnt a ſence.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: So then; thy Queen muſt be confin'd above,
That thou below may'ſt Revel with thy Love:
Looſe me you Slaves, I will not bear this wrong,
I will not ſtir till I have him along.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Oh! the Eternal Plague! my will obey!
This Tempeſt from my Ears with ſpeed convey.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I will not go, you Rebel Slaves forbear;
Jove, to confinement ſend me, if you dare.
All the Coeleſtial Powers ſhall quickly know,
On what Affairs you are employ'd below:
I'le make 'em chuſe another in thy Throne,
To ſave both Heav'n and Earth from be'ng undone.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Guard, wait a while.—

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Nay, now I will not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Will you your Queens, or my Commands obey?
Once more I do inſtate you in my Throne;
Once more this Royal Virgins Vertues own.
Though had ſhe lov'd, it is ſufficient plea
For Innocence, that ſhe's belov'd by me;
For I will be controul'd in no amour;
My Love is arbitrary as my power:
I bound all Minds and Beings, but my own,
Am place to all things, but my ſelf have none.
On you my largeſt ſhare of Love ſhall fall;
But no one Heart has room enough for all.
I like my Sun, my Beams will not confine,
Nor ſtarve all Beings by my ſelf to ſhine.
And like him too, where e're I ſhed my light;
I Nature do not alter, but excite.
When on a looſe and wanton Nymph I ſmile,
Her Blood breeds Monſters like the Mud of Nile:
But when to Flowers and Gardens I repair,
With fragrant Odours I perfume the Air.
Such were the Sweets I from her Vertues drew,
And you ſhall own it, yes and thank her too:
Do it I ſay, and her deſerts proclaim;
She of a Goddeſs only wants the Name.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I will embrace her, ſince I muſt obey;
But ſhe by Heaven ſhall dearly for it pay.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Farewell Fair Nymph!
To that I call my Heav'n I now muſt go;
But leaving you, I leave true Heav'n below.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: From what a horrid Dream do I awake?
I am afraid my Senſe does yet miſtake.
From theſe Coeleſtial Tyrants I amfreed;
But ſtill the Thought does horrour in me breed.
I cannot yet compoſe my reſtleſs Soul,
The Storm is ended, but the Billows rowl.
But oh! which tears my Soul, a ſhame remains;
My riſing Blood does almoſt break my Veins:
A fiery bluſhing flame's around my Face;
I'm all on fire with rage at my diſgrace:
For I'm enough diſhonour'd, and aſham'd
To breath, but in the Air, where Love is nam'd.
But be diſgrac'd with an attempt ſo foul,
I hate this place, the World, the Gods, my Soul.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Tempeſt ended? and no miſchief done?
Caliſto's Innocence unſhaken ſtand?
This horrid Storm muſt be again begun.
I'le fly to Heaven, as Pſecas gave command:
And to my Queen with Lyes my ſelf addreſs,
And bring again that raging Lioneſs.
Mean while I'le charm the Nymphs within this Grove:
Around, around here let'm rove:
And Viſions guard the Sacred ground,
To fright 'em ſtill within their bound.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: How am I kept a Priſoner, in the Power
Of this baſe God? Oh! that revenge to have
I were ſome mighty Goddeſs for an Hour:
Oh! how I would torment the Heavenly Slave?
But ſee! my Siſter here? and oh! my Fears
Her lovely Face all delug'd o're with Tears.
Ah! what means this?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My Siſter here? be gone,
Leave me to my diſorder'd ſelf alone;
And fly theſe Groves, they are the curſt abodes
Of Satyrs, Fiends, or worſe, of Impious Gods.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! how you fright me? I grow pale with fear;
What fatal accident has happ'ned here?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'm too diſorder'd now Replies to make!

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: No matter, I will no denial take.
What has befallen you ſince I parted hence?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What you to hear have too much Innocence.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Not let me know it? this unkind appears;
I will both hear it, and have all the Tears.
To yonder mournful Shades let us repair,
Which to our ſorrows ſome reſemblance bear:
And there to tell your Griefs your Task ſhall be,
And I will ſit and weep for you, and me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: COrydon is a Noble Swain,
And too long has felt diſdain:
But ſince ſcorn I once did ſhow,
My Love I'm too proud to let him know.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Ah Sylvia! Sylvia! my Heart (like yours)
Pain from fooliſh Pride endures.
I angry with Strephon to day did appear,
And now long to reconcile;
Yet in pride for a time will ſeem ſevere,
Though it breaks my Heart the while.

div.stage: Enter Strephon, Corydon, Chorus of Shepheards.
Daphne and Sylvia offer to go as they Enter.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh whither does my lovely Daphne fly?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: How long will Sylvia Corydon deny.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: It is my Will my kindneſs to remove.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I ſhall never, never Love.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh! what has chang'd my Daphne's mind?

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Oh falſe, and cruel Woman-kind!

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Come Shepheards do not complain.
See, ſee yonder a merry Train,
Of Gypſies dancing over the Plain.
Call 'em ſtraight, Call 'em ſtraight to comfort theſe poor Swains.

div.l: No longer complain,
If your Loves ſhew diſdain,
Be proud and diſdain 'em again.
The Fools you will find
Will be glad to be kind,
When they once are deſpiſed by the Men.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Hark, Hark! in yonder Woods the Satyrs Play,
The Ecchoes bring their Laughs this way.
They with ſome pleaſant ſport are pleas'd.
The wanton Demy-Beaſts ſome Nymphs have ſeiz'd.

div.l: Laugh Shepheards, Laugh and Sing;
Joyful Tydings now we bring.
The Fair Caliſto is diſgrac'd;
Gods and Mortals hate the Chaſt.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: All this to me but little eaſe does give.

sp.speaker: Coryd.
sp.l: All Joys are dead to me, why do I live?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: In death alone we eaſe ſhall find.

sp.speaker: Coryd.
sp.l: In death alone we eaſe ſhall find.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: of all. oh falſe and cruel Woman-kind!

div.head: ACT. IV.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: HOW long will theſe malicious Woods in ſpight
Conſpire to hide my Goddeſs from my ſight.
Were the Truth known, ſhe is in private gone
To ſome blind Cave with her Endimion:
For buſie Tongues are with her Honour bold,
Or ſhe with Love does Correſpondence hold.
Some beautious Youths that do her fancy pleaſe,
Have reconcil'd thoſe bloody Enemies;
I ſcorn and hate her, (though theſe falſhoods be)
That ſhe delights in anything but me.
At her my generous Revenge does aim,
I in Caliſto would my Goodeſs ſhame.
But ha! my Vaſſal Mercury ſo nigh?
Put me in humor with ſome pleaſing Lye,
For my loſt Goddeſs I can no where find.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I bring you News (my Nymph!) will tune your mind,
Much better News then did I only aim
To pleaſe and flatter you my wit could frame.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! Speak! the Expectation does delight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The minute that I parted from your ſight,
Our jealous Queen deſcended from above,
And found Caliſto (as you wiſh't) with Jove.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! Joy! and kill'd her ſtreight?—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She was debarr'd,
The Nymph was then under her Lovers Guard,

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: What ſtrange Event muſt that Encounter have?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: All his Queens Rage my Monarch did outbrave.
With her fair Rival forc't her to comply,
Nay, ask her pardon for her Jealouſy.
Not daring then to truth her with his Love,
Compell'd her to return, and fled above.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Tyrant! That I had been his Queen an hour,
I would have plagu'd and exercis'd his power!
Will Juno then put up Affronts ſo rude?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, No, the angry Queen I ſtrait purſu'd,
Fir'd all the Mines of Sulphur in her Soul,
The active Flame through ev'ry Vein did rowl,
That ſhe wept Fire, and her whole Soul did blaze.
The frightned Gods, did at the Wonder gaze,
Believ'd the World once more with Fire undone,
And Jove lookt round for a new Phaeton.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: The World for Ruine ſurely muſt prepare!
Let her deſtroy it, ere Caliſto ſpare.
Oh! I'm impatient till ſhe does appear,
Why tarries Juno? when will ſhe be here?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ere you can think again—I left her now
This inſtant ſtanding on the ſhining brow
Of a Celeſtial Arch, of wondrous height,
With her Robes girt, and ready for her flight.
Caliſho's dead by this time, or at leaſt
Roaring beneath the figure of a Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! Shall ſhe be a Beaſt?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: If any eaſe
It will give you, ſhe ſhall what Beaſt you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! Let me think!—Some very ugly one,
Uglier than yet by Nature e'r was ſhewn
With all her skill and power, let Juno try
To outwit Nature in deformity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She ſhall obſerve your pleaſure to the full,
She ſhall diſcover Natures fancy dull.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: My moſt obedient Deity! But ſtay,
May not Caliſto have eſcap't away,
And found our Goddeſs, whil'ſt you fled above?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I charm'd both her, and Nyphe in that Grove.
There round they wander, chac't by panique fear,
Take for a ſighing Ghoſt each wind they hear;
At their own Voices ſtart, and Shadows ſtare,
And think the lofty Trees tall Fantoms are.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Obſerv'd to every tittle my Command;
Nay, gueſt my very wiſhes, take my hand,
Here pay thy ſelf, for thou haſt pleas'd me ſo,
My Favors unpetition'd I'll beſtow▪
Now Nyphe's Ruine I muſt next contrive;
For no one my diſpleaſure ſhall ſurvive.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For her diſgrace do not diſturb your thought;
Go, let your Goddeſs to the Grove be brought.
To ſhew her Fav'rites virtues there pretend,
My jealous Queen will ſoon your Cauſe defend.
Caliſto's fall will ſome diſhonour throw
On her young Friend, and to purſue the blow,
Charge her with confidence of Love to me.
Then I, as if I fear'd diſcovery,
And of my Miſtriſs Honour cautions were,
Will gently call, but ſo as all may hear,
Nyphe my Love.—My Nyphe, why ſo ſlow!
Come to me here, for I impatient grow.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: How active in Invention doſt thou prove?
Thou half deſerv'ſt the glory of my Love.
I could deſcend to ſmile now, if I durſt;
But that's too great a Favor at the firſt:
And to raſh Youth 'tis an unhappy Fate▪
To come too early to a great Eſtate.
Much Wealth, much Honour, I deſign my Slave,
But I the management of all will have.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My glorious Miſtriſs, does her kindneſs ſhew,
With the vaſt wealth, I ſhould diſtracted grow.
But yet ſome mark of Favor let me wear,
This little Arrow from your Quiver ſpare.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: 'Tis thine!—But ſtay, not that, the Dart you have,
My Goddeſs in reward of Service gave,—
No matter, take it, I her Favors ſlight;
Nay, to affront her, wear it in her ſight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How will I ſtrut among the Powers Divine
With this, and make 'em at my Fortune pine?

sp.speaker: Pſecas?
sp.l: Knight my ſelf I now declare,
And this the Badge of my Queens Order wear.
But ſee the Nymphs walking their Fairy round,
This of their Circle is their utmoſt bound.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! Let me run and wound e'm with my Eye!
But now I think on't—by my Frowns to dye,
Will be a Fate too glorious and ſublime,
And I ſhall look e'm dead before their time.
They are of uſe that Huntreſs to diſgrace,
Which 'cauſe ſhe is of a Celeſtial Race,
Uſurps the Title of a Power Divine,
Though her Deſerts inferiour are to mine.
Howe'r by Birth ſhe's not below my hate,
I'll ſhew her Folly, and diſmiſs her ſtrait.
Then theſe may live.—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: See! See! I have deſcryed
Your Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There by that Rivers ſide—
Run, Run, my Queen!

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: In yonder Thicket ſtay
Till my Return—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My Queen I ſhall obey.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How long ſhall we this black, this curſed place,
The hated horrid Scene of my diſgrace,
In wild and frightful Mazes wander round?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Sure we are here by black Inchantments bound.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Where ere we go, wild ſhapes around us move!
And every Tree appears to me like Jove.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Theſe frightful ſhadows are his Guard I fear,
And for ſome black deſign, impriſon us here.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: They are! What ſhall we for our ſafety do?
Run, and the Fantoms ſwiftlier purſue!
Shoot, and our Arrows flie we know not where,
Are loſt in Miſts, or onely wound the Air.
They come!—Stand off ye Fiends!—

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: How pale they ſhew?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And every thing is blaſted where they go.
That ſome brave Man of the old Tytans Race,
Would help me to revenge my great diſgrace.
If any God will tempt my Soul to Love,
Let him depoſe that hated Tyrant Jove.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! That the Gods ſhould be ſuch wicked things!
Now this into my Soul the Reaſon brings,
Why Heav'n is hated by the Young and Fair;
It ſeems, the Deities abuſe 'em there:
For which, the old and ſlighted do not care.
Is it for this Prieſts bid us worſhip Jove?
Are theſe the Joyes they promiſe us above?
But we are ſafe, my Goddeſs does appear.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Diſguis'd again the Tyrant Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Do you not ſee the Nymphs around her there?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Cheats, Fantoms, all!—Deluſions of the Air.
My heart of fears for you (ſweet Nyphe) eaſe!
Leave me to ſuffer my own miſeries.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Why with unkindneſs do you Love repay?
I hope you do not think I will obey.
Beſides, I'm fetter'd in Inchantments too,
Though I need none to faſten me to you.
The fooliſh Gods may their Inchantments ſpare,
Stronger than theirs about your ſelf you bare.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fortune who ſends me Suff'rings, does in you
Send me the ſweeteſt of all comforts too.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Diſcourſe no more, I cannot bravelier dye,
Than in your aid, and by a Deity.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Then let us bravely periſh in defence
Of injur'd Chaſtity and Innocence;
And when we both are dead, oh! if there be
In Heav'n, but any Friend to Chaſtity.
Some Goddeſs, of our purity have care,
And to ſome private Tomb our Bodies bare.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The chaſte Caliſto ſin? if thou woud'ſt try
To ſcare us with ſome frightful Prodigy,
Thy ſtories within bounds of Reaſon feign;
Thoſe who out-talk their mark, deriſion gain.
Who uſe Invention muſt with Art proceed!
They, of all Merchants, the moſt cunning need.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: I ſcorn the Traffick, and your Friend, nay you
May Love, ere I ſpeak any thing untrue.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Of one moſt uſeful Virtue you have ſtore,
Of Confidence, to charge you with no more.
But know, no ill can her fair Soul invade!
Her whole Compoſure is for Virtue made.
Her Body of ſo pure a mold is wrought,
Her very Body may a Soul be thought!
A Soul to higheſt Purity refin'd!
Viſible Virtue, a Celeſtial Mind
Condens't to Beauty, in that fair diſguiſe
Deſcending to the view of humane eyes.
Groſs Paſſions can no more find dwellings there,
Than Men can breath in the Aetherial Air.
There is no Fuel there for earthy Fire,
The ſtarving Flame muſt inſtantly expire.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! How much curious Art you make appear?
How finely you would paint us nothing here?
Your Colours are ſo fine, your Strokes ſo ſmall,
That they no Strokes, nor Colour have at all.
I know not how inviſible, and pure
Her Body may be, 'tis not ſo obſcure,
But you may ſee her now in yonder Grove;
There but this inſtant in the arms of Jove,
She humbly condeſcended to my view.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I ſay 'tis falſe! Nay, it is Nonſenſe too.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Nonſenſe to ſee! That does indeed ſurprize▪
Nymphs in your ſervice muſt have witty Eyes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That it is Nonſenſe, I again proclaim,
The Gods for her muſt a new Nature frame,
Ere Sin in her the leaſt poſſeſſion gains!
No longer then Caliſto ſhe remains,
Who ſayes Caliſto then does ſpot her Fame,
Sayes ſhe's at once another, and the ſame.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: How for Caliſto you employ your Wit?
How virtuous 'tis to be a Favourite?
Her Crimes with gloſſes as you pleaſe diſguiſe,
You ſhall not argue me out of my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Proceed in inſolent Contention ſtill?
Ceaſe your Diſputes! And know it is my Will,
You never more preſume to touch her Fame,
Nor mention, but with high Reſpect, her Name.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Gods! Gods! to rev'rence her I much incline!
What pity 'tis ſhe is no Power Divine?
Yes! I will ſpread her Virtues, and your own,
What Virtues too they are, ſhall well be known.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Call in diſpute my Virtues?—Seize her there!

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Is this the Love to Chaſtity you bear?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Who boaſt of it ſo much, oft-times have none!

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: My Chaſtity is equal with your own.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Amazing Pride!—Confine her.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: If you dare.
I'll work on Flowers the ſtory with my hair;
Which round the World ſome courteous wind ſhall blow,
Till it with Zeal into a Tempeſt grow.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: With Pride and Malice ſhe begins to Rave;
Conveigh her to ſome Beaſts forſaken Cave.
I doom her by her reſtleſs ſelf to dwell,
And that at once both Fury is, and Hell.

div.stage: As they are guarding her out, Enter Juno, who ſtops them.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Hold! Goddeſs, Do you thus your Nymphs reward,
That with ſuch Loyalty your Honour guard?
Is this the place where Chaſtity's profeſt?
Has Love ſo ſtrong a party in your Breaſt?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Has Love in any Breaſt a greater Foe?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do you your Hatred to that Paſſion ſhew,
By guarding thoſe who wrong my Bed and Throne?
Am I excepted from your Rules alone?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: On any ſuch did e'r my Favour fall,
Who will not bear my Nymphs ſhould love at all?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Does not this Nymph in ſeizure here remain,
For charging the moſt Vicious of your Train?
Whom you from Infamy defend with Might,
For no deſert, but being your Favourite?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The merits of Caliſto well I know,
My Favour raſhly I on none beſtow.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And ſhall my Eyes then be affronted too?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: It was ſome ſhape abus'd both her and you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: That curſed ſhape ſtill ſomewhere haunts this Wood,
And it ſhall bleed if it be fleſh and blood.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: See! with Dart fixt, and Bowe completely beat,
She comes from yonder Grove.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: As if ſhe meant
To give us an Aſſault.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And Nyphe there?—

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Of Virtue ſhe has much her Siſters ſhare.
I thought to tell you (if I durſt proceed)
How Mercury her forward Youth does breed,
And make already moſt expert in Love,
But I perceiv'd I ſhould your Anger move.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Ignorant Nature (if theſe Nymphs be ill)
To temper ſpotleſs Chaſtity wants skill,
Or fleſh and blood is of too courſe allay,
And ſhe may waſte the fires of Souls away,
And in her vain Experiments grow old,
Ere that baſe Metal will be turn'd to Gold.
In them I'm ſure ſhe did at Virtue aim,
And never yet ſo near Projection came.

div.stage: Enter Caliſto and Nyphe in a poſture of defence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now, now the Satyr comes, let us prepare!

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Guarded around with Spirits of the Air
In ſhape of Nymphs.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let's make a brave defence,
Who knows what Charms may be in Innocence?
'Twas Virtue to the Gods their Godheads gave,
Dare they, what made 'em impiouſly outbrave?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: If that gave Godheads, we, who Virtue have,
Are above Gods, and Jove is but our ſlave.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fear not, but valiantly our ſelves defend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: See! See! I think for Battel they intend.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Amazement! let us their intention know.
Princeſs, what mean you by that bended Bow?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Tyrant! I mean to guard my ſelf from you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, and hate you too.
And will my Honour to the death defend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: This is your Royal Virgin.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: This your Friend.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: She knows her guilt too publick to be hid,
So does to Honour bold defiance bid.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why ſacred Honour do you dare to name?
Is Honour, ſince we parted, turn'd to ſhame?
And Vice grown Virtue? Riddles you expreſs.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That Virtue is a Vice which you profeſs.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Practiſe no more on us that ſtale deceit!
You wear that ſhape of Chaſtity to cheat.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The wonder almoſt ſtupifies my Sence;
Run Nymphs, and bring 'em here by violence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stand off you ſhapes, and do not venture near.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Go play your Maſquerading tricks elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stand off, I ſay, if further you proceed,
If ſhapes have any blood, I'll make you bleed.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: See! to the height they Inſolence purſue.
Now to all honour and eſteem for you,
And everlaſting farewell; now I'll know,
If againſt me you dare to bend your Bow.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: We dare, and will.—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And could we make you fly
From your ſtrong Guard of Immortality,
Let Heaven and Nature of themſelves take care,
Or ſtand, or fall, to kill you we would dare.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I'm wounded!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: They to Violence proceed,
And have preſum'd to make a Goddeſs bleed. I
Immortal blood runs trickling from her veins.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! the infernal deed! fetch Engines, Chains!—

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: They ſhall this inſtant at my Altars dye,
I will revenge my injur'd dignity.
Not Jove himſelf ſhall his lov'd Miſtriſs ſave.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: And I the honour of the Prieſthood crave.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'Tis thine the glory to thy zeal is due.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Now all my malice is devotion too.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Like one from ſtrong infernal Chains unbound,
Whoſe Soul is after long diſtractions found,
To Senſe and Reaſon, I begin to wake,
And doubt and tremble at my ſad miſtake.
Is it our Goddeſs? are you Nymphs indeed?
For Heav'n, for goodneſs ſake, reply with ſpeed.
Yet if you do, deluſions ſtill I fear,
Who will ſecure me it is you I hear?
I dare not truſt my cheated ears or ſight.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Ah! Princeſs! do you thus my Love requite?
Do I diſpleaſe you then in being too kind?
And is this wound a puniſhment deſign'd?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Am I betray'd into ſo black a guilt?
Is it your ſacred blood which I have ſpilt?
Oh! Look not on me with that wounding Eye,
Speak not, unleſs to ſentence me to dye.
No other word but death I can endure,
My impious hands from farther ill ſecure.
Kill me, if you deſign Revenge to gain,
Ere I grow mad, and have no ſenſe of pain.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: My Goddeſs cannot ſave me if ſhe wou'd,
For I am fainting in her loſs of blood;
If to her ſelf ſhe does Revenge deny,
I of her bleeding wound alone ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Now they begin again their Syrens Song,
The Tunes which charm'd my Goddeſs Soul ſo long.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Hope they to be forgiven Crimes like theſe?
Abuſe at once two mighty Goddeſſes?
The ſpotleſs blood of chaſte Diana ſhed?
And yet more horrid, durſt invade my Bed?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Believe it, I will ſcorn to make defence,
Nor to beg Life, pretend to Innocence.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: The reaſon for it, is, but too well known!
In ſpite of you, you are ingenious grown.
This injur'd Queen, my Goddeſs here and I
May thank your guilt for ſo much modeſty.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Office, Nymph, I do not underſtand,
Who to implead us gave you the command?
From whom do you derive a place ſo high?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: I ſhall inform you, 'tis from Mercury.
Her Charms that God her humble Vaſſal make;
He would not be a God but for her ſake.
And ſhe that ſhe may kind, and grateful prove,
Revolts from Chaſtity, and ſides with Love.
Nature has to th' amphibious Creature lent
An art to live in either Element.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Malicious! Will you wipe your ſtains on me?
And ſoyle my Honour with your Mercury?
Though could I bow to Love my Noble Sence,
Love then would be a thing of Excellence.
My Nature is ſo Godlike and Sublime,
That nothing I can do can be a Crime.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: My Mercury?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Yes yours, who ſhould he be?
He durſt not have preſum'd to think on me.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Did I not find him with you making Love?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Did I not leave you with him in the Grove?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: You did, but do you not the Reaſon know?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Muſt I a Reaſon for your Vices ſhew?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! Gods! Are there ſuch things, as wrong, or right?
As Truth, and Falſhood? And is Seeing, Sight?
If Truth be true, and Seeing be to ſee,
You love, and are belov'd of Mercury?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Which way can I ſuch confidence confute?
But yonder's one will finiſh our diſpute.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: See, Mercury indeed in yonder Grove!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Liſten, he gently calls.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: within.] Nyphe, my Love.
Steal to me, I will help thee ſafe away.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Steal to thee? who art thou?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: within. Haſte, haſte away.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Villain, Impoſtor, Had I but a dart,
I'd ſteal to thee, and fix it in thy heart.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Now Truth is true, I hope, and Seeing ſight,
Now pray inform us, who is in the right?

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: I am, and this ſome wicked Plot muſt be
Invented by thy lying God, and thee.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Aſtoniſhment! So ſoon to Vice begin?
Your youth an early riſer is in ſin.
Love is in ſo much haſte he cannot ſtay,
But muſt ſet with you ere break of day.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Now where's your Chymiſtry? your beaten Gold?
Your ſpiritual fleſh and blood? A finer mold
Than Souls are made of? All's a Cobweb Cell,
Where her black Soul does like a Spider dwell.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Embitter not thy words with Gall like this!
Treacherous Love has rob'd my Paradiſe,
And pluckt the faireſt Fruit that there did grow;
The Gods in vain, plant Virtue here below.
It ripens not by any Sun or Time,
This World for Virtue is too cold a Clime.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Her thoughts, ſtill for her Favourites, partial ſtay;
Virtue can ſooner faulty be than they.
You may forgive the blood of yours they ſhed,
But ſhe ſhall dye for injuring my Bed.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, let me dye! I many deaths would bear,
Rather than once theſe foul Reproaches hear.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Death on a Rack would be a greater bliſs,
Than Life in ſuch a lying World as this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Chaſte Goddeſs, my Petition is to dye,
Hearken no longer to your Clemency;
Death for your ſacred blood alone is due,
Let me not live to wound your Honour too.
I can a Plea produce yet (if I pleaſe)
Not only all my clamorous Enemies
Could vanquiſh, quite, but ſilence, if I wou'd,
The loudeſt cryes of your immortal blood.
Not only quell my Foes injurious hate,
But make your blood become my Advocate.
That very dart (would I the truth reveal)
Which wounded you, my bleeding Fame would heal.
But that would too much love for life diſplay;
And I ſo hate the evils of this day,
My ſelf I out of Fortunes way would hide!
My Innocence will for it ſelf provide.
If that ſhines by me in my ſhady Tomb,
I ſhall ſleep ſweetly in that mournful Room,
And dream not of the Worlds cenſorious doom.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Unhappy Princeſſes, your Fate's ſevere!
Your Prayers I moſt unwillingly muſt hear,
Your Cauſe I cannot with my Honour own;
A torrent of misfortunes bear you down.
In ſpite of all my kindneſs you muſt dye;
Nay, I muſt baniſh too your memory.
What Plea you have your Innocence to clear,
I cannot gueſs; but I have cauſe to fear
None, that can all theſe Witneſſes oppoſe:
At leaſt, ſubdue the malice of your Foes.
If you ſhall ſuffer an injurious doom,
Oh! may your Honour bloſſom from your Tomb!
I'll build my Arbor there, and every hour
Come and bedew with tears the ſacred Flower.
If you be faulty, and diſgrace your due
Eternal ſhades conceal your names and you.

div.stage: [Diana goes off weeping, Nymphs Guard of Caliſto and Nyphe.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: See! in deep ſorrow ſhe is parted hence!
Her love to Virtue is but a pretence—
She is unchaſte her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Is that unknown?
Have you not heard of her Endimion?
Nor of her young Hippolitus that fled
From every Nymph, in private to her Bed?
She to the World has been a long miſtake!
Pretends to Chaſtity for pleaſures ſake.
For ſecret Love does in the Foreſts dwell!
They underſtand each others meaning well.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: She ſhall diſgrace our dignity no more,
I will depoſe her from her heavenly Power.
And crown thee in her ſtead a Power divine!
I will!—the Empire of theſe Woods is thine.
Mean while I to my firſt Revenge will flie,
Thy Foes and mine ſhall at my Altars dye.—

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! how I am tranſported with ſucceſs!
Courted and ſought by Fame and Happineſs!
But how malicious does my Fortune prove?
Now he comes here to peſter me with Love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My faireſt Queen!

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Thou troubleſt me, be gone!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What change is this?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: I'm buſied in fruition
Of a new Love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you ſay this, to try
If with deſpair I at your feet will dye?
Name him.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: My ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Oh! Now farewell deſpair,
I hope in that fruition I ſhall ſhare.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: I muſt feign Love, that I may freedom gain.
Another time you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Oh! where, and when?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Perhaps this Evening.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: In yonder Grove.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Will you not fail me?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Ask a Maid in Love,
If ſhe will fail to meet with her delight?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: With expectations of this pleaſant Night,
Till it arrives, my thoughts I will employ.—

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Do! Expectation's all you ſhall enjoy.
If in the Grove he tarries till he ſees
Me there, he ſhall ſtay longer than the Trees.—

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Oh! whither are our poor deſpairing Shepherds gone?
I fear I have my Strephon ſlain,

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I my Corydon.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Oh my ſorrow! Oh my pain!
Could I my Strephon find:
Could I my deareſt Strephon find,
I'd never be unkind.
I'd never be unkind to him again.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I, my Love would paſſionately own,
Could I find my Corydon.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Do I Dream? Do I Rave?
Look towards yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Our Shepherds come from yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv. Daph.
sp.l: Our Shepherds come from yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: From empty Pride I'll be free,
It ſhall bring no more miſchief upon me,
Since I Love as well as he,
I'll not hazard my joy,
In being fooliſhly coy,
It had like to have undone me.

div.stage: Daphne and Sylvia go and meet Strephon and Corydon: each brings in her Shepherd.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Dear Strephon, give deſpairing o'res,
Ʋnkindneſſes are gone,
I never will be cruel to thee more.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Nor I to Corydon.

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: O what kind God does Sylvia's hate remove?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And made at length my Daphne grateful prove?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: The God of Love.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: The God of Love.

sp.speaker: Sylv. Daph.
sp.l: The gentle God of Love.

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: Oh happy Tydings!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Bleſſed hour!
Ever kind and gentle Pow'r.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Even kind and gentle Pow'r.

div.stage: Enter Chorus of Shepherds, follow'd by Bacchuſſes.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Joy Shepherds Joy! Diana's diſgrac'd,
Love has had to day Revenge on the Chaſte.
The Bacchuſſes here our mirth to improve,
Come hither to follow the Triumphs of Love.
No mirth without Bacchus, nor joy without Love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Since all our Grief thus joyfully ends,
Let each Shepherdeſs make her Shepherd amends,
To the Temple let's go,
And then we will ſhow,
What every Lover, by Loving intends.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: THE time is paſt, whil'ſt vainly round I pace,
As yet encountring nothing in this place,
But the long Evening ſhadows of the Grove;
And ſhadows are but ſlender food to Love.
Not it is ſubſtance! ſubſtance! muſt delight
Loves wholſom frame and eager appetite.
Malicious Fortune, muſt this ſtay contrive
Some ſudden ill to Pſecas muſt arrive.
Nothing that's common could my Nymph retain,
For when Nymphs love, they fonder grow than Men.
Their melting hearts in kindneſs does excell;
And I am ſure my Pſecas loves ſo well,
That were ſhe dead, her ſpirit would appear,
And leave th' Elizian joyes to meet me here.
Well, patience! patience! time rides proudly by!
And looks upon me with a ſcornful eye;
But I, in ſpite of all his ſwift Career,
Will overtake him, when my joyes appear.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: The mighty Victims ready to be ſlain!
Heavens Queen a Vaſſal to my merits grown.
Diana now no more my Soveraign;
The ſhady Empire of theſe Woods my own?
Th' impoveriſht Stars have nothing to beſtow,
But what for my acceptance is too low.
My next affair is quickly to Caſheer
My loving patient Slave that waits me here.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My Nymph appear? oh! now my Planets ſmile!
What has detain'd thee from me all this while?
〈◊〉 have been wandring here in grief and fear.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Who bid you do't? Could you expect me here?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Can the kind Vows my Queen was pleas'd to make
Her juſt and noble Thoughts ſo ſoon forſake?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Do I ſuch trifling Contemplations uſe?
Will I my Memory with you abuſe?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Though I deſerve not ſuch a glorious place,
My Goddeſs will not from her Mem'ry chace
The noble Creatures which ſhe being gave,
I mean, the promiſes ſhe made her ſlave.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Well, if I did, I'll break 'em if I pleaſe!—
Am I oblig'd to keep my promiſes?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nothing can ſov'reign Power oblige, 'tis true,
But its own will, that ſov'reign Power have you;
But yet there is one mighty thing above▪
Even your own pow'rful Self, and that is Love.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Can any one ſuch Inſolence endure?
Love above me? You would affront me ſure.
Who ſhould, or can I Love? Where is there ought,
(Except my Self?)—that's worthy of my Thought?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True! But ſince Love to me you did expreſs,
Your Love confers on me ſome worthineſs.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: My Love? Why can you think 'twas Love I meant?
Dare you to hope it be ſo inſolent?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why?—ſhould I rudely think you ſpeak untrue?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Am I oblig'd to ſpeak my Thoughts to you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you not Love then?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Dare you hope I do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Are you in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: What ſhould I intend?
Should I with my own Slaves to Mirth deſcend?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And am I fool'd then?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Well! What if you be?
Is't a diſhonour to be fool'd by me?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And will you all my ſervice thus requite?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Challenge Reward, as if it was your right?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your ſervice then is with it ſelf re-paid▪

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Suppoſing not? What ſervice did you do?
Invent a Falſhood? Shame a harmleſs Maid?
Well! when you pleaſe, I'll lye as much for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Exceeding well!—Did I then toyle and ſweat,
At laſt, this Mockery to get?
None ſerve you for your Fools but heav'nly Powers▪

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Mortals are yours, you may ſometimes be ours.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What? then I muſt to your Contempt ſubmit?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: I cannot help another's want of Wit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You do continue in your boldneſs ſtill?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: 'Tis you are bold, who dare diſpute my Will?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thou empty fooliſh Female, who to pleaſe
Thy ſickly Longings, with the fond delight
Of thy vain Sex, or rather their diſeaſe
Of Pride, reſiſts thy nobler appetite.
Though now when thou ſo coy pretend'ſt to be,
Thou'dſt give an Empire I would raviſh thee.
But I'll not ſtoop to gratifie thee ſo;
That joy ſome beſtial Satyr ſhall beſtow!—
Ho! there!—

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: A Rape! here!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Call out if you dare,
I'll all your Lyes and Villanies declare.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Rape! Rape! here!

div.l: So! 'tis well you do appear!
Virtue has excellent protection here.
Much ſafety your good Government affords,
The ſpreading Trees are not ſo full of Birds,
The Caves of Beaſts, as all the Woods around,
Of wanton Gods who ev'ry where abound,
Waiting to make our Chaſtities a prey,
And Gins and Toyles do for our Honours lay.
On our occaſions we can no where move,
But ſtrait we fall into ſome Trap of Love.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Dare you affirm it is a Fault of mine?
Can I the Gods to their abodes confine?
If they be weary of their heavenly bliſs,
Muſt I be guilty?—

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: You are too remiſs.
And both our Honours and your own neglect.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: You are too bold, and full of diſreſpect.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Wherein do I that confidence expreſs?
Is hate to Love and Vice grown ſaucineſs?
Your pardon for my dullneſs I implore,
I never knew they were your Friends before.
It ſeems your meaning we muſt backward read▪
And we a Key to all your Cyphers need.
By Chaſtity, you zealous Love intend;
By Hate and Coyneſs, Kindneſs to a Friend.
Your nimble Wits have found it out;—but I,
Dull Fool, am hardned in my Chaſtity.
You ſhould have plainly told me what you meant,
Before your wanton Gods to me you ſent.
For I affront 'em all, and ſpoil the ſport,
And quite diſorder your myſterious Court.—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Immortal Gods! was e'r Celeſtial Power
In her own preſence ſo blaſphem'd before?
What? I am turn'd a Venus, and my Groves,
Private Retreats, and Nurſery's of Loves.
Hence from my ſight, and in the Foreſt howl,
In ſome Beaſts ſhape, deformed as thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Stay Nymph, and flie to me, I'll have it known,
Here is a Power ſuperior to her own.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What in my Forreſts here have you to do?
I in my Empire am ſupreme to you.
Go exerciſe your Goddeſſhip above,
There you may ſhare authority with Jove.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Your Nymphs diminiſh there my Royal due,
And I will have Repriſals here on you.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Her Love to Virtue now I hope is ſhewn,
And how much wrong I have her Honour done.
She has but one chaſte Nymph in all her Train,
And ſhe enjoys no reſt till that is ſlain.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Boldneſs above belief!—I've watcht an hour
From all theſe cloudy Miſts to ſet you free,
And diſintangle the whole myſtery,
And never yet could get it in my power.
I will no longer bear the pangs and throws,
I now will ſpeak, and none ſhall interpoſe.
She then who dares your anger ſo outbrave,
Is my ſworn Female, my devoted Slave!
Bought to my pleaſure at no dearer Rates,
Than ruining the Nymphs ſhe ſo much hates.
I help to gain her her malicious ends,
And for that hire my pleaſure ſhe attends.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! helliſh falſhood!—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I believe it true!—

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I think it falſe.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Th' opinion is my due!—
I ſcorn to fear he can my Fame remove.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That let th' event of my Relation prove.
I ſhall bring proofs will make your courage fall.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But I will hear it all.
Can you the honour of my Nymphs reſtore?
And are they innocent?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: They are; and more,
Caliſto's Virtue is above Divine,
And Nyphe at the leaſt a Heroine.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: How he exalts the praiſes of his Love?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And flatters ſervilely the vice of Jove.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: In your own preſence dares your Rival praiſe.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: To affront me, he does her Honour raiſe.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: He is no doubt the cauſe of your diſgrace,
And firſt allur'd your Jove to her embrace.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What horrid Monſter art thou? of what kind?
How fortified in body or in mind?
Under what ſpecies does thy Nature fall?
Or humane? helliſh? or Divine? or all?
So many Gods thou dar'ſt deride, defie?
To conquer thee, will be a Victory
Great as the Sun's o're Python, nay above
That over all the Titans gain'd by Jove.
But with the force of Truth I'll make thee bow,
And yet will batter down that brazen Brow.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Melt it with ſhame!—For though ſhe virtuous be,
Malice ſo great diſhonours Chaſtity.
They ſhould not dwell together in one Breaſt,
It is a Serpent in a Phoenix's Neaſt.
Say then, why call'd you Nyphe in the Grove?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Vile Pſecas her diſhonour to remove,
And faſten it on Nyphes ſpotleſs youth.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That was not wiſe, it would not look like truth,
To clear your ſtains with Innocence ſo pure.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Neatneſs alone ſome Maladies does cure.
Contagions ſooneſt taint the fineſt blood,
Unwholſom Rooms they love to change for good.
But us on all theſe pikes her Virtue drove,
She chanc't to make diſcovery of our Love,
And rather choſe a thouſand deaths to dye,
Than hide a crime of the leaſt infamy.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Where lodges truth, if Gods ſuch Lyars be?
He knows all this is only true of me▪
Cauſe by my zeal his Nymph is doom'd to dye,
He ſought Revenge here on my Chaſtity,
And now with falſhoods does my Fame purſue.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Againſt ſuch confidence what can I do?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: What? but your ſelf a foul Defamer own.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Deſpiſe her boldneſs, and the truth make known.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am confirm'd that Pſecas ſuffers wrong.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: If e'r did Nymph from a defaming Tongue.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: With ſacred Truth he does her Honour blaſt,
Why ſhould I judge a mind ſo vicious, chaſte?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Nor Chaſtity, nor any thing that's good,
Can lodge in one that ſhares Caliſto's blood.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: My Vice, (I fear) to your diſgrace will prove,
Too much ſeverity to Vice, and Love.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Hermes! Releaſe me from this Viper here!—
Who in my ſacred Honour, does not fear
To fix her Teeth, and Venom to diſtill▪
On that, which is an antidote to ill.
Make but Caliſto's Fame, as Nyphe's clear,
And this bold Nymph a puniſhment ſevere,
For all her Blaſphemies ſhall quickly bear.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: When he clears her, then you do what you dare,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Her divine Virtues, and unſpotted Fame,
Incenſe and Victims only ſhould proclaim.
All wordiſh praiſe ſhe is ſo much above,
That Eloquence would Prophanation prove.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! how the Woods muſt with her praiſes ring?
Such were the words entic't her to his King.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Praiſe on—and Pſeeas's Reproaches ſlight,
Torment her envious Nature to the height.
And did Caliſto triumph over Jove?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O'r him, o'r Pleaſure, Empire, Glory, Love.
Deſpairing to ſubdue by open ſtorm,
He firſt ſtole to her in your beautious form,
Hoping by ambuſh his deſign to gain;
And finding that fair ſtratagem in vain,
Himſelf and all his glory he diſplay'd;
Himſelf his Heaven at her feet he laid,
He ſu'd, commanded, threatned, and implor'd,
Nay, wept, bow'd, kneel'd, and at her feet ador'd;
But could not or by promiſe, force, or guile,
Entice, compel, or cheat her to a ſmile.
Her Fort of Chaſtity to buy, to break,
Heaven was too poor, Omnipotence too weak.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: This to torment you ſure is ſome deſign.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It tears my ears.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: 'Tis harmony to mine.
The brave Caliſto's praiſe ſtill boldly tell!
My Pleaſure is their Rack, my Heav'n their Hell.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Fond Goddeſs, who triumpheſt in thy ſhame,
Preferring thy vain Fancy to thy Fame;
Contending in thy Favourites defence,
Againſt thy Honour, Reaſon, and thy Sence.
If all I can affirm no Faith can gain,
Believe thy wound, and liſten to thy pain.
Hark how thy blood thy Favourite commends!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That very blood will prove her beſt of Friends.
And only be (when you the reaſon know)
To your malicious hopes a mortal blow,
Jove in your ſhape deep on her Soul impreſt,
And ſtrongly with the horror ſtill poſſeſt.
The ſight of you new terrors did awake,
She did your perſon for your ſhape miſtake.
And that deceiv'd her to a Crime ſo brave,
She aim'd at Jupiter the blow ſhe gave;
You of his ſufferings alone complain,
You have the wound, but Jupiter the pain▪
A Crime will to her endleſs Fame redound.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Gods! then I muſt reward her for my wound.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You ought!—but how?—the Virtue ſhe has ſhown,
Not all the Lawrels in your Woods can crown.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Happy the moment when my blood was ſpilt!
I'll now have Altars to my Victims built.
Their glory ſhall exceed their paſt diſgrace!
Bring 'em in triumph here to my embrace.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Oh! Gods! this impious ſentence who can bear?
This is a plot betwixt theſe Gods and her,
Wholly to ruine Virtue by degrees,
That they may love and revel as they pleaſe.
Nay, glory in it too, and make it prove
A Virtue worthy high rewards to Love.
And ſhortly all will Chaſtity diſclaim,
And to be virtuous, will be thought a ſhame.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh! moſt provoking!—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Her reproach diſdain,
Her ſland'rous tongue ſhall quickly end its Reign.
I'll fetch a ſov'reign Judge ſhall quell her pride,
And this debate impartially decide.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: She names but half your villanous deſign,
You plot my glory too to undermine.
Ungrateful Jove, now weary of me grown,
Will place my Rival in my Bed and Throne,
And it is plotted here among you all!
And my ſevere Revenge on thee ſhall fall.
I'll kill thy Nymphs, thy Reputation blaſt,
Throw down thy Temples, lay thy Foreſt waſte.
Thy ſelf from Cave to Cave with Tempeſts chace,
And in the ſavage Beaſts an inſtinct place;
To tell 'em who their Murdereſs us'd to be,
And make 'em for Revenge go hunt out thee.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh! fooliſh Rage! which will no Reaſon hear!
Your Fury againſt me I ſcorn to fear.
Alas! your anger at your equal flies;
But yet, perhaps, you may my Nymphs ſurprize.
I to their Innocence the more incline,
Your Honour to reſpect as well as mine.
But ſince you fight your own diſgrace to prove;
I'll both defend 'em againſt you and Jove.
sp.stage: [Enter Caliſto, Nyphe vailed, brought in by Nymphs.
sp.l: Come Princeſſes! this poſture is not due!
Truth has unvail'd it ſelf, and ſo may you.
Your Beauties are not brighter than your Fame,
Falſhood and Malice you have put to ſhame.
For the Rewards of Virtue now prepare,
And ſcorn the utmoſt which your Foes can dare.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Oh! What kind Power has the Truth reveal'd?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: One that has all our wounds entirely heal'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And your wound too! For unleſs that be whole,
My Honour may be well, but not my Soul.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: So well, that I am better than before!
My courage greater, and my pleaſure more!
If I have any pain, 'tis that which flows
From the exceſs of joy, your Fame beſtows:
The mark of which, upon my arm I bear;
The onely Jewel, I am proud to wear.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! Glorious News! Who proves the Lyar now?
Great Goddeſs ſome Revenge to us allow.
The impious Author there of all this Evil,
Let's offer up a Victim to the Devil:
But ſhe in miſchief does ſo much excell,
Pluto, in fear, will keep her out of Hell.
She'll be a greater Plague than any there;
Furies themſelves will be afraid of her.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Did ever Falſhood Virtue ſo outbrave?
Great Goddeſs, on my knees, Revenge I crave.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You fierce, tempeſtuous Spirits of the Air,
Who late confin'd me, to my aid repair.
sp.stage: [Enter Spirits, the Nymphs ſtand on their Guard.
sp.l: The favour which you forfeited regain;
The Honour of your injur'd Queen maintain:
Theſe bold Rebellious Nymphs in pieces tear,
And throw their Limbs in Whirlwinds round the Air.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Approach who dares! nay, for permiſſion pray
To blow out of my Woods one Leaf away.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: Oh! Goddeſs! let 'em come! for I'm in pain
Till one of 'em at leaſt by me is ſlain.

div.stage: As they are ready to Encounter, Enter Jupiter and Mercury.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Muſt I my Heav'n eternally forſake,
To quiet the diſorders which you make?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Return'd again?—Oh! moſt tormenting ſight!
There, I reſign to you, your ſole delight.
Make her your Goddeſs in the room of me,
I'll bear no more the Royal mockery,
Nor be a Statue to adorn your Throne.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And are you weary then of Empire grown?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am, and of my life!—And to be free,
Deſire no bleſſing like Mortality;
That my own hand might pour out with my blood,
My ſorrows and my life!—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I wiſh you cou'd!—
That both of us and all the World ſome eaſe
Might find of your eternal Jealouſies.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Who is in fault?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Your folly is the cauſe,
For I will not be limited by Laws;
You but in part my kindneſs can enjoy,
My Ocean muſt a thouſand Springs ſupply.
Once more I own this Royal Maid, I ſtrove
To tempt by all the arts of Threats, or Love;
But 'gainſt her Virtue did no more prevail,
Than the old Gyants when they Heav'n did ſcale.
They pil'd up hills on hills my Throne to ſeize,
I Mountains heapt of golden promiſes;
But found her Virtue from my reach as far
As from my Palace all their Mountains were.
Like thoſe fond Fools when I was moſt ſublime,
I did but in the reach of Thunder climb.
Her Soul ſhot down ſuch Lightning from her Eyes,
Inſtead of ſpoiling, I ador'd my prize.
Once more embrace her then, and after this
The leaſt injurious thought of her diſmiſs;
And Mercury the wrong which you have done
That fair young Nymph with low ſubmiſſions own.
And to whatever ſuff'rings ſhe thinks fit
To ſentence you, with Penitence ſubmit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I gladly to her fair Tribunal come,
And humbly on my knees attend her doom.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: I recompence enough from this receive,
Revenge and Malice to your Nymph I leave.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And thoſe good Virtues, which her gentle Mind
So much adorn, ſhe ſhall rewarded find.
Now you, who with ſuch zeal the ruine ſought
Of theſe fair Nymphs, ſhall to your doom be brought.
I hope my words they credit may afford,
And all for truth acknowledge!—

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Oh! Inſolence! Charge me with Falſhood too?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Falſhood, I hope, is falſe, though ſpoke by you.
Power gives not language the more truth or ſence.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Aſtoniſhing! drag her to Torments hence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Spare her, for I my Honour ſcorn to owe
To her Acknowledgments.

sp.speaker: Ny.
sp.l: No, let her go.
For ſhe has done, and let her ſuffer ill.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Now I will ſtay to contradict your will.
The Fondlings dandled upon Fortunes Knee
Nere ſav'd, ('tis true!) from my conſpiracy.
But to no merit have the leaſt pretence,
Excepting pure inſipid Innocence.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Your judgment (if you pleaſe, great Pſecas!) ſpare;
We (with your leave) of that ſole Judges are.
Oblige us now your Reaſon to relate,
Why you purſu'd the Nymphs with ſo much hate.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: My hatred ſtoop to have concern for them?
You much miſtake, the Error I contemn.
Seeing what fondneſſes abus'd your mind,
Having ſome kindneſs for you, I deſign'd
To diſabuſe you, ſet your judgment right,
And honour you with being your Favourite.
But ſince you from your own good Fortune go,
And have not Wit enough deſert to know,
I throw you wholly out of my eſteem,
And no ſubmiſſion ſhall the loſs redeem,
Though in deep ſorrow at my feet you fall;
For now I ſcorn you, nay, I ſcorn you all.
Gods, Goddeſſes, and Nymphs, away I'll flie,
And keep no more ſuch trifling company.
I'll hunt alone, and in my ſelf delight,
And be my own moſt dear-lov'd Favourite.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: She is grown frantick!

div.stage: [Pſecas offers to go, is ſtaid by Juno.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Rather ſhe is brave.
Stay gen'rous Pſecas, I thy friendſhip crave,
Bury not all thy worth in a Retreat;
Give me thy Love, and I will make thee great.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: A moſt harmonious friendſhip this muſt prove!
The Fates deſign'd 'em for each others Love.
For none love them, and they have love for none;
Their kindneſs centers on themſelves alone.
And they are ſo exactly of a make,
Each may the other for her ſelf miſtake.
Now muſt the laſt and heavieſt ſentence fall
Upon my ſelf the greateſt Criminal.
My wretched ſelf (as to my Crimes is due)
I doom to part eternally from you.
And to the pain of heav'nly joy to go;
But yet I muſt not leave you here below.
In pity to the World, I muſt remove
Thoſe fatal eyes, out of the reach of Love.
Love muſt not here thoſe killing darts retain,
To wound and torture Gods, and murder Men.
And yet to place you in my Heav'n, would be
Not your Reward, but my Felicity.
Some middle Region I muſt prepare,
Where all may with ſome eaſe your Beauty bear.
I then entreat, you will (to end this War!)
Accept the ſmall dominion of a Star.
There you and beautious Nyphe may diſpence
With cooler beams your light and influence.
On the great Ceremony Hermes wait,
Let all the Gods give their appearance ſtrait.
Theſe Virgins Conſecration nought debars,
I'll in a full Aſſembly crown 'em Stars.

div.stage: Enter Strephon, Corydon, Daphne, Sylvia, Chorus of Shepherds, as from the Temple.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Happy Lovers! happy Live,
And all the Gods their bleſſings give.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Lead along, and with Delight,
Let us haſten on the Night.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: What Viſion's this is come to greet us?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: See! the Night is come to meet us.

sp.speaker: 1 Afr.
sp.l: Stay gentle Swains be not afraid,
To ſee our Faces hid in ſhade.
We, but lately, were as fair,
As your Shepherdeſſes are.
Did not a frantick Youth of late,
O'reſet the Chariot of the Sun?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: He did, and his deſerved Fate
He met when he had done.

sp.speaker: 2 Afr.
sp.l: It is he that hath undone us:
He powr'd whole ſtreams
Of melting beams,
Red, and glowing hot upon us.
And now we range the World around,
To ſee if our loſt Beauty can be found.

sp.speaker: 3 Afr.
sp.l: Rejoyce, Rejoyce: our Beauty's found,
Our lovely White and Red,
To two chaſte Nymphs of Cynthia's Train is fled,
And they muſt Stars be crown'd:
And now inſtead of what we ſought,
Our Black with us muſt fair be thought.
This happy Fate, who could Divine?
Our Beauty then in Heav'n muſt ſhine.

sp.speaker: 1 Afr.
sp.l: No Loſers we ſhall prove,
By parting with our Red and White;
If black will ſerve the turn of Love;
For Beauty's made for Loves delight.

sp.speaker: 3 Afr.
sp.l: See! See! the Nymphs are coming here.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: But Oh! what glorious Apparition's near?
The Clouds amazing Glories gild:
All the Clouds with Gods are fill'd.
And all the Gods appear.

div.stage: Caliſto and Nyphe enter under a Conopy, ſupported by Africans; immediately upon their entrance, a Heav'n is diſcover'd, fill'd with Gods and Goddeſſes.
The whole concludes with an Entry of Africans; and this Song.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Muſt theſe be Stars? And to Heaven remove,
Before they have taſted the pleaſures of Love.
That the Gods ſo ill, ſuch Beauty ſhould uſe!
What mighty Coſt muſt Nature loſe?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I cannot ſo much Beauty ſhow,
But what I have, I'll better beſtow.
Not upon Gods, or Glories above,
Or empty Renown, but Pleaſure and Love.
All pleaſure but love, from our hearts we'l be chaſing,
We'l kindle our ſelves into Stars with embracing:
We'l every moment our pleaſures renew,
Our Loves ſhall be flaming, and laſting and true.

div.head: The Epilogue ſpoken by Jupiter, who deſcended out of the Heaven, and addreſſed himſelf to Caliſto and Nyphe.
div.l: THE Stars for your Reception now prepare,
And the ambitious Heav'ns expect you there;
But I will ſpoil their hopes, and break my vow,
For I've conſider'd there are Stars enow:
And this inferiour World can ſcarce diſpence
With the entire loſs of ſo much Excellence.
With each of you I can oblige a Throne,
I'll keep you then to grace ſome Fav'rite Crown.
On that deſign you here ſhall ſtill remain,
And I'll diſſolve into a Nymph again.
Which will no leſs this fair Aſſembly pleaſe;
For Nymphs, in Courts, have ſway like Deities.
You Wits who think you Gallantry diſplay,
To laugh at ev'ry thing a God can ſay,
Will in good manners to a Nymph ſubmit,
And own whatever Beauty ſpeaks for Wit.
Perhaps the power of Beauty to expreſs,
We chooſe our Language careleſs as our Dreſs.
None ſhould come hither to attend, but gaze;
Here Beauties charms not Wits you ought to praiſe.
And 'tis your ſafeſt courſe, judge you of Show,
Fine Cloaths, and Faces, Tunes, and Dances too;
For thoſe are things which you may chance to know.
There is no doubt but you have ears and eyes,
Your underſtanding moſt in queſtion lies.
But what do I here trifling thus with theſe?
There are the Powers to whom we ſacrifice,
In whoſe great Preſence I may well allow
To lay aſide my uſeleſs Godhead now.
You, Sir, ſuch bleſſings to the World diſpence,
We ſcarce perceive the uſe of Providence.
And ſince Your Rule ſuch joy to all procures,
All ſhould contribute what they can to Yours,
Wit by Your Smiles a Luſtre do's maintain,
And Beauty keeps a long and happy Raign.
Your Right in them is therefore ſo entire,
They, above all, Your Pleaſure ſhould conſpire.
